item.title: Simultaneous detection and quantification of leukemia fusion gene isoforms from RNA-Seq data in AML
item.description:
Introduction and objective

One of the earliest fusion genes discovered in the history of biomedical science is a fusion between the BCR gene and the ABL gene. This creates the fusion protein BCR-ABL, which is the cause of a common type of leukemia known as t(9;22) CML.

Since then, many different leukemia fusion proteins have been reported and shown to act as drivers in various leukemias. One of these is AML1-ETO, which arises from the chromosomal translocation t(8;21) and is responsible for 10-15% of all cases of acute myeloid leukemia (AML). While AML tends to affect older patients, t(8;21) AML appears to affect children and young adults more frequently. At the molecular level, AML1-ETO is an in-frame fusion between the DNA-binding domain of the AML/RUNX1 gene and most of the ETO/MTG8/RUNX1T1 protein, missing a small portion of the N-terminus, which is a non-conserved sequence in ETO family proteins. At the DNA level, a fusion occurs between intron 3 of RUNX1 and intron 1 of ETO.

Figure 1: Expression of exon 9a in an t(8;21) AML detected by RNA-Seq and location of the t(8;21) translocation site

Figure 2: The marked sequence and its upstream region are translocated into the ETO gene in t(8;21) AML

There are 12 exons for the ETO gene in the official human reference genome. However, Dr. Dong-Er Zhang found that one unannotated exon is transcribed to generate an alternative splice variant of AML1-ETO. This exon was designated exon 9a and the corresponding AML1-ETO variant was designated AML1-ETO9a (Yan, M., Kanbe, E., Peterson, L. et al. A previously unidentified alternatively spliced isoform of t(8;21) transcript promotes leukemogenesis. Nat Med 12, 945-949 (2006)). While full-length AML1-ETO has 752 amino acids, AML1-ETO9a has only 542 amino acids. This is because exon 9a, if retained after splicing, would introduce a premature stop codon in frame.

At the protein level, AML1-ETO9a lacks a C-terminal sequence that is present in the full-length protein. This sequence has been shown to interact with proteins involved in transcriptional repression. It is not yet known whether the amount of AML1-ETO9a has an impact on disease progression. One way to address this question is to compare the prognosis of patients who have high or low levels of AML1-ETO9a at diagnosis. However, the results are controversial. While early studies suggested that AML1-ETO9a expression was associated with poor prognosis in t(8;21) AML [ref], a recent work by Agrawal M et al Functional and clinical characterization of the alternatively spliced isoform AML1-ETO9a in adult patients with translocation t(8;21)(q22;q22.1) acute myeloid leukemia (AML). Leukemia. 2020 Feb;34(2):630-634 showed that the level of AML1-ETO9a did not affect prognosis.

Another possibility is that AML1-ETO9a expression, although not a prognostic factor at diagnosis, increases after treatment in a manner that promotes disease progression. In this case, we would expect AML1-ETO9a expression to be increased in relapsed AML.

The goal of this study is to develop an algorithm to detect the fusion genes using RNA-Seq data and quantify the expression of their isoforms. For the above reasons, we focused on the AML1-ETO isoforms.

Methods

We used the Kallistosoftware to quantify transcript levels. Kallisto quantifies the expression of a given transcript by aligning the reads to a transcriptomic index created from the sequences of available transcripts in the genome. In our case, we created a custom index by replacing the ETO/RUNX1T1 isoforms with the sequences of FL AML1-ETO and AML1-ETO9a. The RNA-Seq of the patient samples were downloaded from the NCI TARGET AML database.

Results

Expression of AML1-ETO9a is detected in all AMLs with known t(8;21) status and some AMLs with unknown or nagative t(8;21) status.

Figure 3: Expression of AML1-ETO FL and AML1-ETO9a

As you can see, we found that AML1-ETO9a was expressed in non-t(8;21) AMLs, including AMLs with “unknown” t(8;21) status and AMLs with negative t(8;21) status, as determined by assays such as FISH. One possibility is that these assays were not sensitive enough to detect the presence of fusion genes.

Detection of AML1-ETO fusion transcripts by STAR-fusion and Kallisto-fusion tools.

Some algorithms have been developed to detect fusion genes based on RNA-Seq data. We tested two such algorithms, including STAR -fusion and Kallisto-fusion. Both algorithms found that the two AMLs with an “unknown” t(8;21) status but expressing high levels of AML1-ETO9a indeed had fusion between AML1 and ETO. Interestingly, the Kallisto- fusion found that several AMLs with negative t(8;21) status but expressing detectable levels of AML1-ETO also contained AML1-ETO fusion transcripts.

Figure 4: Detection of AML1-ETO fusion by STAR-Fusion

Figure 5: Detection of AML1-ETO fusion by Kallisto-Fusion

AML1-ETO9a expression at the time of diagnosis was not correlated with disease progression.

Figure 6: AML1-ETO9a levels at diagnosis cannot predict patient outcome

### AML1-ETO9a levels are significantly elevated in t(8;21) AML in relapse.

Since we have now determined AML1-ETO9a levels at both diagnosis and relapse, we wanted to know whether its expression changed significantly at relapse compared with diagnosis. This required the use of paired AMLs, for which 5 cases were available for t(8;21) AML.

Figure 7: AML1-ETO9a is significantly increased at relape in t(8;21) AML

The results showed that the expression of AML1-ETO9a significantly increased in t(8;21) AML at relapse. This suggests a role for AML1-ETO9a in promoting disease progression in t(8;21) AML.

Conclusion

A Kallisto-based algorithm (FusionQuant) has been developed to simantaneouly detect and quantify leukemia fusion genes.

AML1-ETO9a levels at the time of diagnosis do not correlate with survival.

AML1-ETO9a levels are significantly increased in relapsed AMLs, suggesting a role for AML1-ETO9 in disease progression.

item.title: Exploring the relationship between gene expression and leukemia prognosis in Shiny
item.description: The acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is one of the most devastating forms of cancer. AML prognosis is determined by many factors. Here, we build a dynamic application in Shiny to explore the relationship between patient prognosis and gene expression.
